head.title: Hisses and Groans Greet Plan To Replace Tappan Zee Bridge

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Hisses and Groans Greet Plan To Replace Tappan Zee Bridge

abstract.p: Public hearing held at Westchester County Center on proposal to reduce traffic congestion on Interstate 287 by replacing Tappan Zee Bridge; number of nearly 100 people who attend question estimated $4 billion cost of project (M)

block.p: With catcalls, boos and groans, residents showed their displeasure, skepticism and anger last night toward a proposal to reduce traffic congestion on Interstate 287 by replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge, which links Westchester and Rockland Counties.

A number of the nearly 100 people who attended a hearing at the Westchester County Center -- the first of four public hearings scheduled over the next two weeks -- questioned the estimated $4 billion cost of building a wider bridge and a proposed commuter rail line across it, and whether the money could be found.

With catcalls, boos and groans, residents showed their displeasure, skepticism and anger last night toward a proposal to reduce traffic congestion on Interstate 287 by replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge, which links Westchester and Rockland Counties.

A number of the nearly 100 people who attended a hearing at the Westchester County Center -- the first of four public hearings scheduled over the next two weeks -- questioned the estimated $4 billion cost of building a wider bridge and a proposed commuter rail line across it, and whether the money could be found.

Residents also said they believed the governor's task force that made the recommendation in a report last month as part of a study of congestion on the 30-mile Route I-287 rushed to recommend demolishing the current bridge rather than exploring options that residents said would be less costly and disruptive.

''We are not saying there should not be a replacement bridge,'' said Hazard Gillespie, president of the Tappan Zee Preservation Coalition, a Piermont resident and a retired United States attorney for the southern district of New York. ''But we do say before you reach that conclusion, let's have an independent study.''

Although John Platt, executive director of the New York State Thruway Authority and a member of the five-person task force, told the audience ''we don't see any land-taking for the Tappan Zee Bridge replacement nor the causeway'' leading up to it, the statement was met with a tide of hisses and moans. There was widespread concern that a wider bridge would inevitably bring more traffic and pollution.

Members of the governor's I-287 Task Force generally did not answer questions; the hearings are intended to gather opinions. But staff members did present a brief overview of their work, stressing that their report recommended a combination of solutions to ease congestion on Route I-287, from Suffern to the New England Thruway.

The task force also suggested expanded use of bus shuttles and park-and-ride lots and varying the tolls on the bridge to induce commuters to use it during off-peak hours. But replacing the bridge, it said, was fundamental. A decision on how to proceed is not due for another several months, Mr. Platt said.
